repnme.cdata!:
Sustainable management of natural resources
            and mainstreaming of biodiversity in the Cape Floristic
            Region in South Africa

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Development
            Project in South Africa. The Cape Floristic Region (CFR) is
            the smallest and richest of the world’s floral kingdoms and
            entirely contained within South Africa, with more than 9,600
            species of plants. The CFR biodiversity hotspot provides a
            multitude of essential ecological services and livelihood
            opportunities. The project enabled the more effective use of
            economic incentives to induce changes in land user behavior
            in favor of conservation stewardship. The project
            successfully refined conservation planning, promoting
            biodiversity considerations in spatial planning and water
            resource management, thus mainstreaming biodiversity into
            economic development and poverty alleviation strategies,
            while at the same time leveraging the alignment of normal
            government budgets. Notably, it resulted in successfully
            expanding the area of terrestrial habitats under
            conservation management, between the mountain and lowland
            habitats to the sea. The project also resulted in an
            increase of endangered and critically endangered ecosystems,
            under conservation, from an initial 16,115 hectares to
            61,603 hectares, through stewardship agreements with private
            landowners and communities.

docna.cdata!:
Gestion durable des ressources naturelles et
            prise en compte de la biodiversité dans la Région florale du
            Cap en Afrique du Sud

25202336.trustfund:
BBGEF-BB GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL FUND,TF053225-GEF3 FSP-SOUTH AFRICA:CAPE
            BIODIVERSITY AND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT PRO,TF051243-GEF2:SOUTH AFRICA-CAPE ACTION
            PLAN FOR THE ENVIRONMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
South Africa - Biodiversity Conservation
            and Sustainable Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Biodiversity
            Conservation and Sustainable Development Project for South
            Africa were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; the risk
            to development outcome was low or negligible; the
            Bank's performance was satisfactory; and the
            Borrower's performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: biodiversity conservation and
            sustainable development project. The project demonstrated
            the catalytic effect that strategic use of incremental
            Global Environment Facility (GEF) resources can have in
            bringing about substantial change. The project was designed
            and implemented with the donor and governmental financing
            situation in mind, so that it could focus on incremental
            benefits that otherwise will not likely be attained. Project
            implementation involved considerable use of adaptive
            management to adjust to changing conditions, unforeseen
            constraints, and new opportunities. Achieving success in
            biodiversity conservation-and many other aspects of
            sustainable development-typically requires sustained
            commitment over a relatively long time frame.

14667645.trustfund:
BBGEF-BB GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL FUND,TF051243-GEF2:SOUTH AFRICA-CAPE ACTION
            PLAN FOR THE ENVIRONMENT PROJECT,TF053225-GEF3 FSP-SOUTH AFRICA:CAPE
            BIODIVERSITY AND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT PRO

repnme.cdata!:
South Africa - CAPE Biodiversity
            Conservation and Sustainable Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project Objective is to support the
            conservation of the Cape Floristic Region (CFR) and adjacent
            marine environment by laying a sound foundation for scaling
            up and replicating successful Project outcomes. The project
            has the following six components: Component 1) will align
            and strengthen institutions to conserve the CFR. It will:
            (i) enhance interagency cooperation and strategic planning
            for conservation management, (ii) build capacity for
            effective conservation management, (iii) develop and
            appraise strategies for financial sustainability across the
            suite of Project Executing Agencies; and (iv) establish a
            shared and comprehensive information management system to
            share the most important knowledge requirements. Component
            2) will support the development of a conservation education
            and awareness program to conserve the CFR. It will: (i)
            facilitate coordinated environmental education; and (ii)
            develop and disseminate materials focused on biodiversity,
            supportive of informal and formal education curricula,
            including training of educators to capitalize on the
            favorable education policy environment. Component 3) will
            strengthen the C.A.P.E. Coordination Unit at the NBI to
            undertake: (i) program coordination and management; (ii)
            financial management of the overall Project; (iii) program
            portfolio management and coordinated monitoring and
            evaluation to assess lessons learned, and support and
            develop a replication plan; and (iv) a communication
            program. Component 4) will expand the protected areas. It
            will: (i) plan and consolidate three large protected area
            complexes involving private landowners and inhabitants as
            beneficiaries; (ii) establish two freshwater, two estuarine
            and two clusters of marine protected areas; (iii) develop
            sustainable management effectiveness of protected areas
            through implementation of a Strategic Performance Management
            System, and (iv) develop a harmonized protected area
            information management systems, plan for responsible tourism
            investment and visitor impact mitigation in four protected
            areas. Component 5) will mainstream biodiversity
            considerations into economic growth and development, It
            will: (i) integrate fine-scale conservation plans in five
            priority target areas into government spatial planning and
            regulations at municipal level; (ii) increase landowner
            commitment to conservation through coordinated extension
            services and cooperative management schemes in priority
            target areas; and (iii) develop and pilot financial
            incentives to conserve biodiversity in threatened lowland
            habitats. Component 6) will address watershed management and
            freshwater and estuarine protected areas in key intervention
            sites: (i) increase the effectiveness of the
            "Ecological Reserve" measure in water resource
            management in three watersheds, and incorporate biodiversity
            concerns into the new fire management systems being
            implemented; (ii) create an alien invasive species
            management strategy and business plan for the entire CFR,
            and pilot the control of invasive aliens in certain priority
            ecosystems; and (iii) design and test a CFR estuarine
            management program, based on relevant case studies.

2848378.trustfund:
TF051243-GEF2:SOUTH AFRICA-CAPE ACTION
            PLAN FOR THE ENVIRONMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
South Africa - CAPE Action Plan for the
            Environment Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This document sets out a resettlement
            policy framework for the C.A.P.E. Program, in accordance
            with the Bank operational directives, and the country's
            environmental laws and regulation, aimed at ensuring the
            living standards of those affected by the implementation of
            the project are improved, or at least restored. Eligibility
            shall apply to landowners, corporate institutions, farm
            occupiers, land users, users of marine resources, and,
            individuals or companies providing support to commercial
            forestry. Involuntary resettlement shall be avoided as
            possible, though viable alternatives shall be explored to
            ensure sustainability to those affected. The environmental
            nature of the project entails a project design that provides
            potential opportunities for building capacities, and benefit
            communities as a result of its environmental protection
            components, and eco-tourism possibilities, as well as
            markets for environmental services. Nevertheless, tenure
            security, loss of income, and restriction of land use, and
            access, including physical relocation will occur. To this
            end, the Executing Agencies have embarked on an extensive
            concessioning program for eco-tourism facilities, and
            services in protected areas, and, one of the key sources of
            benefits for local populations is the opportunity that
            arises from these concessions. The content of concession
            agreements will include provision for them to address
            resettlement impacts, and access government programs for
            housing and land subsidies. Capacity building and training
            will be provided as a safeguard across a wide range of
            institutions. Monitoring and evaluation should ensure
            compliance with the principles of this framework, and
            grievance mechanisms will be in place should conflict occur.

South Africa - CAPE Action Plan for the
            Environment Project : resettlement plan

2815633.trustfund:
TF051243-GEF2:SOUTH AFRICA-CAPE ACTION
            PLAN FOR THE ENVIRONMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
South Africa - Cape Action Plan for the
            Environment Project : environmental and social management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental and social
            management framework for South Africa's Cape Action
            Plan for the Environment Project, which is a large-scale,
            multi-faceted GEF funded conservation program aiming to
            conserve, restore, and enhance biodiversity in the Cape
            Floral Kingdom and the adjacent marine environment, and
            deliver significant economic benefits to the region. The
            report identifies potential impacts from project activities
            consolidating key protected areas, such as socio-economic
            impacts due to restricted/loss of access to resources
            (affecting communities impacted by the mega reserve process;
            loss of agricultural land or productivity; impacts
            associated with the upgrading or construction of
            infrastructure (linked to tourism development or the
            development of small and medium enterprises); and management
            plans for the estuaries that involve developing
            infrastructure in the (unlikely) event that rivers are
            diverted or weirs constructed. Only project activities
            related to developing infrastructure for an extensive
            concessioning program for eco-tourism facilities and
            services in protected areas will also  trigger the
            environmental assessment process (EIAs). Infrastructure
            would include roads, sewage treatment works, al structures
            below the high water mark (HWM), dams, reservoirs, schemes
            for bulk water supply, and waste disposal would require
            EIAs. Activities such as land reclamation below the HWM,
            changes in land use, and any anticipated damage to natural
            habitats and cultural property will also require EIAs.
